title: Clarice Smith
text:
Clarice Smith (1933-2021) was an American painter and portraitist whose paintings have appeared in a number of exhibitions in the United States and Europe. With her husband, <a href="Robert%20H.%20Smith%20%28philanthropist%29">Robert H. Smith</a>, Clarice Smith engaged in philanthropy, especially at the <a href="University%20of%20Maryland%2C%20College%20Park">University of Maryland</a>, where the <a href="Clarice%20Smith%20Performing%20Arts%20Center">Clarice Smith Performing Arts Center</a> is named for her, and at <a href="George%20Washington%20University">George Washington University</a>, where the couple endowed the Smith Hall of Art. They also initiated a distinguished lecture series at the <a href="Smithsonian%20Museum%20of%20American%20Art">Smithsonian Museum of American Art</a>.
Education.
Born Clarice Chasen to a <a href="American%20Jews">Jewish</a> family, Smith studied art at the <a href="Corcoran%20School%20of%20the%20Arts%20and%20Design">Corcoran School of the Arts and Design</a> and the University of Maryland. She received her MFA in 1979 from George Washington University, where she taught as a member of faculty from 1980 to 1987. Smith, who described herself as a "lifelong learner," cited a "Methods and Materials" class at George Washington University, "where she first learned about paints," as the beginning of her career as an artist. In 2012 she received an honorary doctorate from George Washington University, and in 2015 was awarded a Doctorate of Humane Letters from the University of Maryland.
Career.
Clarice Smith worked as a professional painter for forty years, and exhibited in group and solo exhibitions in both the United States and abroad, in the United Kingdom, France, Switzerland, the Netherlands, and Israel. Among her most notable exhibitions are those at the <a href="National%20Museum%20of%20Women%20in%20the%20Arts">National Museum of Women in the Arts</a> (2009), <a href="Virginia%20Museum%20of%20Fine%20Arts">Virginia Museum of Fine Arts</a> (2011), and the <a href="New-York%20Historical%20Society">New York Historical Society</a> (2013). In 2016 her work was paired with that of the sculptor <a href="Albert%20Paley">Albert Paley</a> for an exhibition at the <a href="Kreeger%20Museum">Kreeger Museum</a> in Washington, DC. Her painting "Big Race" (2001) is in the permanent collection of the Smithsonian American Art Museum.
She also published several written works along with her son <a href="David%20Bruce%20Smith">David Bruce Smith</a>. They include "Afternoon Tea with Mom", a collection of her paintings, "Three Miles from Providence," historical fiction about <a href="Abraham%20Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a>, "Continuum", a collection of Venetian paintings for the National Museum for Women in the Arts, and "Tennessee," a collection of unpublished <a href="Tennessee%20Williams">Tennessee Williams</a> plays.
